items.name: Kathy YL Chan
items.shortBio: Kathy YL Chan is a tea authority based in Honolulu and NYC. She sources, consults, and travels in search of all things tea.
items.bio: Kathy has shared her travels around the world for over a decade at [kathyylchan.com](http://kathyylchan.com/). Tea is the unifying thread in all her adventures, from Paris to Taipei. Whether it be taking afternoon tea in a grand hotel or visiting tea plantations tucked deep in Kyoto, she believes that tea is the most rewarding ritual that transcends all languages and cultures. When not traveling, Kathy splits time between NYC and Honolulu writing about and consulting for luxury brands and clients on all things tea.

items.hed: Tea Salons: How to Try Some of the World’s Rarest Teas
items.dek: From the seductive Maison des Trois Thés in Paris to the iconic Wistaria Tea House in Taipei, these are the most unique tea salons around the world.
items.seoTitle: Tea Salons: How to Try Some of the World’s Rarest Teas
items.socialTitle: Tea Salons: How to Try Some of the World’s Rarest Teas
items.body:
*There are places for afternoon tea, there are retail tea shops...and then there are tea salons. These are mystical places where sitting for hours over a serving of tea is not only allowed, but encouraged. Often, there's an educational component so that you can learn about teas and tea ceremonies while you drink. From the seductive Maison des Trois Thés in Paris to the iconic Wistaria Tea House in Taipei, these are the most unique tea salons around the world.*


[#gallery: /galleries/549065561a6990a8482fc184]||||||





[#image: /photos/542ed67be0ce0bdc0faf402d]||||||

##[Wistaria Tea House](http://www.wistariateahouse.com/)

Wistaria Tea House is an iconic tea salon offering a tea experience that is pure and uncluttered. Situated in the Da’an District of Taipei, this spot is rich with cultural and political history—it's a former government residence that became a meeting place for the intellectual set, and is now a national monument; not to mention, it serves a selection of top-notch teas from Taiwan. Order an oolong (we suggest the high mountain jin xuan), and it’ll be delivered and steeped with water sourced from the Wulai mountain springs.


[#image: /photos/542ed67488114e6e3ffce45f]|||
Maison des Trois Thés
|||

##[Maison des Trois Thés](http://www.maisondestroisthes.com/)

It’s all about Chinese teas at Maison des Trois Thés in Paris. Run by tea master Yu Hui Tseng, this tea salon marries Chinese tradition with French sensibilities. The result is a seductive experience with tea brewed at the table in the traditional *gongfu* style (with small cups and a slotted tray). Every tea offered should be steeped multiple times, the flavors evolving with each round. Take it easy and take it slow—this is a place to relax.


[#image: /photos/542ed677e0ce0bdc0faf400f]|||
The Best Tea House Co., Ltd.
|||

##[The Best Tea House Co., Ltd.](http://www.besttea.com.hk/eng/eindex.htm)

A well-regarded tea master and inventor of the pu’erh dry storage method, Vesper Chan also owns The Best Tea House Co., Ltd., a group of tea shops throughout Hong Kong. For the full experience, you’ll want to book an appointment with the master himself at the Kowloon location, which houses a secret upstairs room and Vesper Chan’s private collection of tea and teaware.


[#image: /photos/542ed674e0ce0bdc0faf4000]|||
Jugetsudo
|||

##[Jugetsudo](http://www.jugetsudo.fr/) 

Jugetsudo is located in the posh 6th arrondissement of Paris and specializes in Japanese teas. The tiny corner boutique is half retail shop and half tea tasting room. Pull up to a seat at the counter and order one of the specialty green teas. We’re partial to matcha and the umami-rich gyukuro (pictured), both served with homemade *wagashi* (traditional Japanese sweets).


[#image: /photos/542ed677e0ce0bdc0faf4010]|||
The Mandarin's Tea Room
|||

##[The Mandarin's Tea Room](http://www.themandarinstearoom.com/)

On a second floor building of Howard Street in SoHo is the legendary Tim Hsu of The Mandarin's Tea Room. Appointments are required for private 90-minute tea sessions, each personally hosted by Tim and tailored to the guest. Whether you’re just diving into the world of tea or a seasoned expert, you’ll walk out of this tea room enchanted and infinitely more knowledgeable.
items.seoDescription: From the seductive Maison des Trois Thés in Paris to the iconic Wistaria Tea House in Taipei, these are the most unique tea salons around the world.
items.socialDescription: From the seductive Maison des Trois Thés in Paris to the iconic Wistaria Tea House in Taipei, these are the most unique tea salons around the world.

items.name: Aran Goyoaga
items.shortBio: Aran Goyoaga of [Cannelle et Vanille](http://www.cannellevanille.com/) is a regular contributor to *Condé Nast Traveler* magazine, covering stories about food, travel, and food culture all around the world.
items.bio: Aran Goyoaga is an author, food stylist, and photographer based in Seattle. Her food blog [Cannelle et Vanille](http://www.cannellevanille.com) is a two-time James Beard Award finalist and was named the no. 2 best food blog in the world by the *UK Times.* Aran grew up in the Basque Country in Northern Spain in a family of professional pastry chefs and cooks. She worked as a pastry chef herself for years before turning her focus to photography. She is also the author of *Small Plates and Sweet Treats: My Family’s Journey to Gluten-Free Cooking* (Little, Brown & Co), which was named one of the top six cookbooks of 2012 on *Good Morning America*. Aran’s work has been featured in *The New York Times,* Gwyneth Paltrow’s *GOOP, Jamie Magazine, Bon Appetit, Saveur,* Martha Stewart’s Everyday Food, Whole Living, Coastal Living, Fine Cooking, *In Style,* CNN, *Miami Herald, Living Without,* Oprah.com, *ELLE* Gourmet, Design Sponge, *Sweet Paul* magazine, PBS.com, Daily Candy, NBC Latino, and more. Aran works out of her downtown Seattle studio where she offers photography and styling workshops.

items.hed: Food Photography Tips for Instagram and Smartphones
items.dek: Everyone knows that food is the best part of traveling—and sharing food photography on Instagram is one way to capture those memories. Here's how to take the best #nofilter pics of your favorite culinary finds.
items.seoTitle: Food Photography Tips for Instagram and Smartphones
items.seoDescription: Everyone knows that food is the best part of traveling—and sharing food photography on Instagram is one way to capture those memories. Here's how to take the best #nofilter pics of your favorite culinary finds.
items.socialTitle: 9 Tips for Taking Flawless Photos of Your Food
items.socialDescription: Everyone knows that food is the best part of traveling—and sharing food photography on Instagram is one way to capture those memories. Here's how to take the best #nofilter pics of your favorite culinary finds.

items.title: __Start with the perfect lighting.__
items.caption: Lighting is really important. Focus on one key light, and try to block other conflicting light sources. Always avoid lightbulbs that are directly overhead. If you are in a dark restaurant, get close to a window with natural light; or go outside, but stay in the shaded area closest to direct sunlight. While shaded areas eliminate direct overhead light, the light will be completely flat if you go *too* deep into a shaded area.

items.title: __Play around with color.__
items.caption: If the light is bad but you are still happy with composition, simply turn the photo into black and white.

items.title: __Get to know your angles.__
items.caption: Overhead and straight-on angles tend to work best with food, because many smartphone cameras have wide-angle lenses. Having said that, try shooting from other angles every so often to get a new perspective.

items.title: __Don't forget your lines.__
items.caption: If you do play around with angles, make sure you consider your distance from the subject so the photo doesn't get distorted—especially with interior shots. Be patient, frame your shot, and don't shoot until your composition looks perfect.

items.title: __Let the food be the star.__
items.caption: Because is difficult to achieve great *bokeh* (very shallow depth of field), really pay attention to which background you choose. Try to avoid surfaces or backdrops that are too distracting from the food or get too close to your subject.

items.title: __Composition is key.__
items.caption: Try to avoid filling the frame with too many elements; I find it effective to have a bit of negative space in the image. You can also crop into elements to add a bit of interest and tension to the image.

items.title: __Capture movements.__
items.caption: When shooting restaurants, food, and lifestyle images, take advantage of movement. Freeze the space, but capture the human elements through movement. Once you have framed the image, patiently wait until people walk in front of your frame, then shoot away while you stand in place.

items.title: __Follow the #nofilter trend.__
items.caption: You don't need to use Instagram filters for food. Instead, try other photo editing apps like [Snapseed](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/snapseed/id439438619?mt=8), [VSCO](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/vsco-cam/id588013838?mt=8), or [Afterlight](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/afterlight/id573116090?mt=8). We all know what food should look like, so when colors and tones are altered, the image just looks fake.

items.title: __Focus on branding, not perfection.__
items.caption: Post photos on Instagram that represent your style, with a variety of angles and subjects that stay within your personal “theme.” I think what makes an Instagram account interesting is when someone shows their photography skills while taking risks and staying away from perfection. Not every photo needs to be perfectly styled.

items.name: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell
items.shortBio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell are food writers with a passion for seasonal food, great desserts, and inadvisable wine pairings. Read more on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net).
items.bio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell have been chronicling their passion for simple, seasonal recipes since 2008 on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net). After almost a decade of life in Brooklyn, they recently moved with their family to the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Virginia where they live happily near the farmers and producers that inspire their work. Elizabeth is a regular contributor to Food52 where she writes the 'Salad Days' column. Her work has also appeared online on Saveur.com, Cosmopolitan.com, and People.com among others, and in print in *Vegetarian Times* magazine.

items.hed: The Beer Lover's Guide to Europe
items.dek: From Altbier to Zoigl, drink your way across the continent with these unique European beer destinations.
items.seoTitle: The Beer Lover's Guide to Europe
items.seoDescription: From Altbier to Zoigl, drink your way across the continent with these unique European beer destinations.

items.title: Bamberg, Germany
items.caption: While Munich is better known as a beer destination, Bamberg is also a Bavarian gem. It's home to nine breweries, many of which are located in the astoundingly well-preserved old town (a UNESCO World Heritage site). Rauchbier, a beer that derives its smoky flavor from malt dried over an open flame, is the local specialty, and you can sample it at [Schlenkerla](http://www.schlenkerla.de/indexe.html), the most famous Rauchbier brewer, or [Spezial](http://www.brauerei-spezial.de/), another brewery with an outstanding pedigree. [Klosterbräu](http://www.klosterbraeu.de/index.php?sitevar=geschichte), also in the old town, has been brewing since 1533 and offers a variety of beers if you discover Rauchbier’s not your thing.

items.title: Plzeň, Czech Republic
items.caption: The birthplace of pilsner, Plzeň (or Pilsen) merits a visit from any American beer-lover who wants to pay homage to the pale lager. A short drive or train ride from Prague, Plzeň boasts charming medieval and Renaissance buildings, including one of the largest synagogues in Europe. But the biggest tourist attraction is the Pilsner Urquell brewery, the oldest maker of pilsner in the world. You can take tours of the brewery year-round. And just outside the city, there are plenty of smaller traditional breweries like [U Stočesů](http://www.ustocesu.cz/) and Modra Hvezda that make fabulous day trips.

items.title: Namur, Belgium
items.caption: Belgium is such a beer paradise that you can likely throw a dart at a map and hit a great brasserie, farmhouse brewery, or quaint beer-brewing abbey. But the region around Namur, in the center of the country, offers beer-lovers some truly unique experiences. In addition to the [brasseries](http://www.bocq.be/) and [abbeys](http://www.chimay.com/en/chimay-experience.html?IDC=756), there are one-of-a-kind sites like the [Museum of Belgian Beer](http://www.belgium-tourism.be/tourisme/description.php?RG=o&CLANGUE=EN&ID=720&T=VC&ELTOID=32417&REGION=O&INSCOM=0&INSANCCOM=0&QUERY_LOC=&) and, for the true beer nerd, the [Gambrinus Drivers Museum](http://www.gambrinus-drivers-museum.be/indexen.htm), devoted entirely to beer trucks.

items.title: Brussels, Belgium
items.caption: Brussels and the rolling farmland in Pajottenland (to the west of the city) are home to beer-makers producing a variety of beer styles. For visiting hops-heads, it’s the Lambics that make it most worth the visit. Venerable breweries like [Cantillon](http://www.cantillon.be/) offer tours, as does the [Brewer’s House](http://belgianbrewers.be/), a trade organization for brewers in a magnificent baroque building that also has a museum dedicated to Belgian beer.

items.title: Leipzig, Germany
items.caption: Leipzig may not be as popular with travelers as Berlin or Munich, but its eclectic mix of Renaissance storefronts, Baroque commercial buildings, and Neoclassical residences make it an excellent spot to explore. For the beer-drinking traveler in particular, the city offers Gose, a pleasantly sour, salty beer originally from Goslar but now associated with Leipzig. Try Gose at the [Gasthaus & Gosebrauerei Bayerischer Bahnhof](http://www.bayerischer-bahnhof.de/en/startseite/index.html), a decommissioned railway station that now serves as a brewery and pub, or take a short trip to Goslar (also in Saxony) to [Brauhaus Goslar](http://www.brauhaus-goslar.de/).

items.title: Düsseldorf, Germany
items.caption: Although it’s one of Germany’s largest cities, in Düsseldorf’s *Altstadt,* you’ll feel like you’re in a Medieval village. And if you feel like a beer, you’re in luck because the *Altstadt* is also known as the “world’s longest bar,” as it’s home to more than 300 of them in less than a square kilometer of real estate. You’ll especially want to check out Altbier, the crisp-tasting, copper-colored beer that’s Düsseldorf’s local specialty. In the Altstadt, you’ll find four breweries that make it: Füchschen, Uerige, Schlüssel, and Kürzer.

items.title: Burton upon Trent, England
items.caption: While you can find excellent beers throughout England (especially cask ales), Burton upon Trent has been famous for its beers since the 18th century and is still home to eight breweries today. Start your visit with a trip to the National Brewing Centre, displaying everything from refurbished steam engines from Victorian breweries to vintage beer trucks to carriage rides pulled by Shire horses. [Marston Brewery](http://www.marstonsbrewery.co.uk/tours.aspx), the world’s largest cask ale brewer, offers a popular tour, while the charming downtown has plenty of pubs with [Cask-Marque accreditation](http://cask-marque.co.uk/), which means their cask ale is of the highest quality.

items.title: Dublin, Ireland
items.caption: Irish stout may serve as the jumping off point for beer connoisseurship for many Americans, so Dublin is a natural pilgrimage to make. Inside the [Guinness Storehouse](http://www.guinness-storehouse.com/en/Index.aspx) at the iconic St. James’s Gate Brewery, you can stand at the bottom of the world’s largest pint glass, learn about the brewing process step-by-step, see exhibits on storage and advertising, and try your hand at pouring a pint. If microbrews are more your style, check out [The Porterhouse](http://www.porterhousebrewco.com/bars-dublin-temple.php) which brews and serves its beers in Dublin’s Temple Bar District.

items.title: Upper Palatinate, Germany
items.caption: To truly geek out on a beer trip, Upper Palatinate’s legendary Zoiglbier is something of a Holy Grail. Brewed in communal breweries in only five villages (Eslarn, Falkenberg, Mitterteich, Windischeschenbach, and Neuhaus) near the Czech border, Zoigl is sold on a rotating basis by the various families who man the brewery. You can tell which house is selling it on a given day by looking for a six-pointed star hanging in front of the house. But schedules can be dicey and it’s entirely possible you’ll trudge out of town without so much as a sip. If you do manage to procure some, you’ll find it to be a malty beer with a deep amber color. If you decide to start your own quest for Zoigl, Windischeschenbach and Neuhaus are said to be the easiest to access by train but all five villages are overflowing with quaint historic charm.

items.title: Cologne, Germany
items.caption: Germany’s fourth largest city boasts everything from a cathedral that’s a gothic masterpiece to famously wild nightlife, but for beer fans, it’s the place to go for Kölsch, an easy-drinking pale beer with very mild bitterness. The most famous breweries are [Reissdorf](http://www.reissdorf.de/), [Gaffel](http://www.gaffel.de/en_Home.html?ActiveID=2062), and [Früh](http://www.frueh.de/) and you can find all three at pubs throughout the town, though only Gaffel and Früh offer tours of their own. If you want to dig a little deeper, check out [Sünner Keller](http://www.suenner-keller.de/brauereibesichtigung.html), the city’s oldest brewery.

items.socialTitle: The Beer Lover's Guide to Europe
items.socialDescription: From Altbier to Zoigl, drink your way across the continent with these unique European beer destinations.

fields.name: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell
fields.shortBio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell are food writers with a passion for seasonal food, great desserts, and inadvisable wine pairings. Read more on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net).
fields.bio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell have been chronicling their passion for simple, seasonal recipes since 2008 on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net). After almost a decade of life in Brooklyn, they recently moved with their family to the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Virginia where they live happily near the farmers and producers that inspire their work. Elizabeth is a regular contributor to Food52 where she writes the 'Salad Days' column. Her work has also appeared online on Saveur.com, Cosmopolitan.com, and People.com among others, and in print in *Vegetarian Times* magazine.

items.name: Lilit Marcus
items.shortBio: Lilit Marcus is *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor.
items.bio: Lilit Marcus is a Brooklyn-based journalist and *Condé Nast Traveler*'s contributing digital editor. Her first book, *Save the Assistants: A Guide for Surviving and Thriving in the Workplace,* was published by Hyperion. Lilit's favorite destinations include Lisbon, Tel Aviv, Nashville, and Mexico City. Her work has also appeared in The Wall Street Journal, Glamour, The Guardian, Cosmopolitan, and The New York Observer.

items.hed: Weird Candy From Around The World
items.dek: One of the best ways to learn about a new culture is to try their favorite sweets. Whether you’re sampling fragrant musk sticks in Australia, salted licorice hard candies in Finland, or chili powder-coated gummy spaghetti in Mexico, your dessert has never been so interesting.

items.title: [Salmiakki] (http://www.amazon.com/Fazer-Super-Salmiakki/dp/B002GXA8FQ)
items.caption: Just because it’s candy doesn’t mean it needs to be sweet. Scandinavians love their *salmiakki,* a salted black licorice. It’s sold in hard and soft candy form but also used as a flavoring for liquor, ice cream, and soda.

items.title: [Musk sticks] (https://www.simplyoz.com/products/australian_foods/sweets__lollies__chocolate__candy/lollie_bags/black__gold_musk_sticks)
items.caption: These pink sugary confections, popular in Australia and New Zealand, taste like musk—a flavor that most people associate with strong cologne.

items.title: [Bamba] (http://www.amazon.com/Osem-Snacks-Flavored-3-5-Ounce-Packages/dp/B000S67NZ6)
items.caption: Bamba may look like cheese doodles, but don’t expect them to be savory—these Israeli treats taste more like peanut butter.

items.title: [Zombie Food] (http://www.necco.com/Broker/Files/Product-Images/Halloween-2012/33258-Skybar-Zombie-Food-1oz-Single.aspx)
items.caption: These seasonal candies, produced every Halloween by sweetmaker Necco, have bloody red caramel inside body parts (including, of course, braaaaaaains).

items.title: [Tequila Lollipops] (http://www.hotsaucecatalog.com/tequila-lollipop-with-real-worm/)
items.caption: What? You *didn’t* want a worm in your candy?

items.title: [Wasabi Kit Kats] (http://www.amazon.com/Japanese-Kit-Kat-Wasabi-Chocolate/dp/B00859PXXM)
items.caption: Outside of the United States, Kit Kats come in fun flavors like white chocolate, strawberry, cinnamon, *yuzu,* green tea—even wasabi. If you like your chocolate with a bit of heat, this is the candy for you.

items.title: [Lightning Bug Gummy Candies] (http://www.royalcandycompany.com/lightning-bugs-candy-5117.html?gclid=CJmd9e24osECFc1Z7AodvEgAnw)
items.caption: It’s totally OK to play with your food, provided your food is one of these lightning bug-shaped gummies, which actually light up when you squeeze them with a special pair of tweezers.

items.title: [Salsagheti] (http://www.amazon.com/Lucas-Salsagheti-Gusanos-Sandia-24-0-85oz/dp/B004J0UF2K)
items.caption: If you’ve ever wanted to eat dinner and dessert at the same time, this Mexican candy can help – their texture is kind of like Twizzlers, except they’re thinner, fruitier, and coated in chili powder.

items.title: [Cheese & Onion Potato Chip Flavored Chocolate Bar] (http://www.taytocrisps.ie/about-tayto/tayto-chocolate-bar/)
items.caption: Irish potato chip company Tayto had an unexpected hit with their limited-edition chocolate bar flavored like a cheese and onion chip. It was so popular that they had to add it to their regular product lineup.

items.title: [Durian Candy](http://www.amazon.com/Homark-Durian-Candy-6-34-Ounce/dp/B00AQT21WA)
items.caption: Durian is definitely an acquired taste – the fruit has a strong, pungent gym-sock-esque smell that has gotten it banned in some public places. In Southeast Asia, you can find durian-flavored hard candies.

items.title: [Chocolate-Covered Crickets ](http://www.candywarehouse.com/products/chocolate-covered-crickets-24-piece-display/)
items.caption: Although Americans are still skittish about eating bugs, other countries consider chocolate-covered insects a real delicacy. Crickets have a nice crunch to them.
items.credit: Courtesy I Ate a Bug Club/CandyWarehouse

items.title: [Bertie Bott’s Every Flavour Beans ](https://jellybelly.com/product/596)
items.caption: These jelly beans, whose flavors include Vomit and Snot, started off as a creation in the *Harry Potter* book series but are now a real thing. If you get a Vomit bean, you can’t say nobody warned you.

items.seoTitle: Weird Candy From Around The World
items.seoDescription: From wasabi Kit Kats to zombie chocolates, check out some of the world’s wackiest candies.
items.socialTitle: Weird Candy From Around The World
items.socialDescription: From wasabi Kit Kats to zombie chocolates, check out some of the world’s wackiest candies.
